passage_text: When using bleach baths for eczema treatment, you are asked to take a bleach bath for about 10 minutes twice a week. More frequent baths can be useful for more severe eczema or during specific eczema flare ups.

Recent research has shown that bleach baths can be extremely significant for children with eczema. 7 year old Ben participated in a trial in 2006 that changed his life according to his mother, Jennifer. He had severe eczema on his calves, and it would crack and swell, causing infections and scarring.

Bleach baths make the tub into a swimming pool! Use ½ cup household bleach for a full bathtub, ¼ cup for a half bath. Soak for about 10 minutes and rinse off. Use 2 – 3 times a week. Bleach baths decrease the bacteria on the skin and decrease bacterial skin infections.

A bath with a small amount of bleach added to the water may help lessen symptoms of chronic eczema (atopic dermatitis). Eczema is an itchy skin condition, often worsened by a bacterial infection. An eczema bleach bath can kill bacteria on the skin, reducing itching, redness and scaling.

1 Add 1/2 cup (118 milliliters) of bleach to 40 gallons (151 liters) of warm water — that will fill a U.S.-standard-sized bathtub to the overflow drainage holes. 2  Use household bleach, not concentrated bleach.

If properly diluted and used as directed, a bleach bath is safe for children and adults. For best results: 1  Add 1/2 cup (118 milliliters) of bleach to 40 gallons (151 liters) of warm water — that will fill a U.S.-standard-sized bathtub to the overflow drainage holes. 2  Use household bleach, not concentrated bleach.

After three months, the children on the regimen of bleach baths and an antibiotic ointment (applied to the inside of the nose) had fewer sores and a decrease in eczema severity, while 70 percent of children with the placebo treatment remained the same and 15 percent were worse.
